III.    Facility Identification

The Bridge Western facility is located at 2635 South Western Avenue in Chicago, Illinois.  The facility is refrigerated warehouse that is utilized for refrigerating and freezing a variety of food products. The NAICS code for the facility is 49312. 



The facility uses anhydrous ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There is one refrigeration system onsite that is used for refrigerating and freezing a variety of food products. The total amount of ammonia onsite is approximately 20,000 pounds, which is above the minimum threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds.



The refrigeration system provides the mechanical refrigeration required for maintaining temperatures in the freezer, blast freezers, holding coolers, product re-pack area, and the inspection areas.



An area map identifying the site location is included as Appendix A.

Appendix B contains the RMP*Submit Printout and includes additional information on the worst-case scenario.  Appendix B contains the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the worse case release scenario.

Appendix B contains the RMP*Submit Printout and includes additional information on the alternative release scenario.  Appendix D contains the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the alternative release scenario. 



VI.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program

A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   



This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above

the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules.  The elements of the PSM, Program 3 prevention program, and a brief description are listed below.

?    Employee Participation - Bridge Western has developed a site specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing a process hazard analysis and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  In addition, the employee participation program will ensure employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  

 

?    Process Safety Information - Bridge Western maintains a site specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained.

?    Process Hazard Analysis - Bridge Western has developed a site specific process hazard analysis (PHA) program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, and at a minimum, every five (5) years, and whenever required by the written Management of Change program.  In addition, this program ensures PHA's are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHA's are properly documented.  Bridge Western completed the most recent PHA revalidation study on  August 27, 2013.

?    Operating Procedures - Bridge Western has developed a site specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.  Bridge Western completed the most recent review of the standard operating procedures on October 29, 2013. 

?    Training - Bridge Western has developed a site specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems.

?    Ma

nagement of Change - Bridge Western has developed a site specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented.

?    Pre-Startup Review - Bridge Western has developed a site specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.

?    Mechanical Integrity - Bridge Western has developed a site specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  

?    Contractor Qualifications - Bridge Western has developed a site specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers' safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Bridge Western and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency action plan and control over entrance into process areas.

 

?    Incident Investigation - Bridge Western has developed a site specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed.

?    Compliance Audit - Bridge Western has developed a site specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years

to verify that Bridge Western PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed.  The next compliance audit will be conducted in May, 2016.

?    Hot Work Permits - Bridge Western has developed a site specific best management practice for hot work.

?    Emergency Action Plan - Bridge Western has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that contains procedures designed to maximize the safety of all employees, contractors, and visitors in the event of an emergency and also guard against environmental consequences.



VII.    Five-Year Accident History

The Bridge Western facility has not had an accidental anhydrous ammonia release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five years.



VIII.    Emergency Action and Response Plan

Bridge Western has developed an Emergency Action and Response Plan (EARP) to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release. 



Bridge Western currently relies on their ammonia refrigeration contractor to respond to any emergencies related to the ammonia refrigeration system. 



The facility has two (2) windsocks present onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release and evacuation of the building.



The current Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix E. 



IX.    Emergency Communications

The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are available onsite.



X.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Chemical safety is an important part of Bridge Western operations. Bridge Western recently conducted a process hazard analysis of their ammonia refrigeration system and will be dutifully implementing the recommendations from the

assessment. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Bridge Western. 



XI.    Management Program

Bridge Western has developed a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or positions) to assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organizational chart or similar document.  Currently, Jerry Weilert, Plant Engineer, is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.
